title: Toulouse-Lautrec and the Celebrity Culture of Paris
description:
WALL TEXT
The entertainment industry exploded in late nineteenth-century Montmartre, a gritty neighborhood on the outskirts of Paris known for its flamboyant nightlife and bohemian atmosphere. Artists, performers, and ambitious entrepreneurs flocked there to capitalize on the cheap rent and lack of police oversight, and the crowds of Paris quickly followed to see the raucous performances at the new cabarets and dance halls. The spirited establishments of the quartier fed into a thriving culture of celebrity, where singers and dancers such as Jane Avril, Aristide Bruant, and May Milton—all depicted in this gallery—sought widespread notoriety and critical acclaim. 

Painter and printmaker Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec moved to Montmartre in 1882, and he dedicated his career to depicting the district’s famous personalities, who were often his close friends. Using the relatively new advertising technique of large-scale posters, Lautrec regularly collaborated with performers, writers, and cabaret owners who wanted to distinguish themselves from their competitors. Lautrec’s dynamic and recognizable images, displayed throughout the streets of Paris, quickly catapulted his clients to stardom. Instead of idealizing his subjects, he chose to celebrate their individuality by emphasizing their unique traits. In doing so, he was also able to promote his own cutting-edge artistic endeavors, which included experiments in color lithography, the use of unconventional techniques and materials, and a continued observation of modern life’s cast of characters.
short_description: This focused installation features dynamic and instantly recognizable works by Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec that helped catapult his clients to fame.
